# Python 3, ~~89~~ 76 bytes

- -13 thanks to @ovs

```
lambda m:[[max(x*y//3for x in r[:i]+r[i+1:])or y%3<1for i,y in enumerate(r)]for r in m]
```

Try it online!

Takes input as list of lists of integers. Outputs same format.

The idea here is simple enough; each element should be replaced with either itself or its maximum neighbouring nonzero element modulo 3. The only trickiness comes from handling edge cases correctly without too much code bloat. We use integer division instead of floor division because this allows us to handle both edges at once using one condition rather than two separate conditions. This also means we don't actually care about whether elements are positive or negative since they will always round down anyway. Finally, note that when checking neighbours we must check *all* neighbours including diagonals but exclude ourselves. For example, given \$a_{ij}\$, we would consider \$a_{(i\pm1)(j\pm1)}\$. However, we cannot simply iterate over these indices directly due to wrapping around the ends of rows/columns. Instead, we first take slices excluding the current row/column before concatenating back together again. In python slice notation, taking everything up until index \$n\$ inclusive is written like `[:n+1]`. So, e.g., `r[:i]+r[i+1:]` gives every item in row `r` apart from position `i`. Note that this works even though `i` may equal `len(r)-1` which might otherwise cause problems. That's because `r[i+1:]` returns nothing in such situations meaning no extra items get added onto the end. Similarly, `r[-1::-1][:-i-1]+r[i:]` does the equivalent thing for columns.
